page.title: 17Frenchay Village History
page.content: In the 15th and 16th centuries there were corn, flock and snuff mills working on the river Frome and pennant stone was quarried locally, so the millers and quarry men founded the earliest settlement. During the next two centuries the village became the centre of a thriving Quaker community, William Penn of Pennsylvania U.S.A becoming associated with the village through marriage. Many of Frenchay's large beautiful houses were built at this time by the rich merchants from Bristol. The wooded parklands they stand in survive today. The village was designated a Conservation area in 1975 so it still retains its rural atmosphere of river, wooded valley, commonland, parkland, gracious houses and small cottages, together with modern well-designed housing developments on its perimeter.
